overview: A 9-week mini-course in real-world money math: paychecks, budgeting, percent applications, banking, credit, taxes, and investing. Every lesson uses actual numbers — not motivational posters. Students learn to read a pay stub, build a budget, compare loan options, and make evidence-based financial decisions.
naturalProgression: Establish money vocabulary and read a real paycheck
Build a monthly budget with fixed, variable, and irregular expenses
Apply percent fluency to discounts, tax, tips, and unit pricing
Understand savings accounts, interest, and emergency funds
Analyze credit cards, loans, debt traps, and amortization
Compare job offers using take-home pay and benefits
Explore investing, compound growth, and long-term planning

aiInstructionModel.approach: AI-led gradual release with real-world financial contexts
aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads instruction using the gradual release model, grounded entirely in realistic financial scenarios. Every concept uses actual dollar amounts, real tax rates, and plausible life situations. The goal is financial decision-making, not just computation.

phases.aiRole: Introduce the financial concept with a concrete scenario. Define vocabulary in plain language. Connect to what students already know about money.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the scenario, identify key terms, connect to personal experience

phases.aiRole: Walk through 2-3 worked examples using realistic numbers. Show the math AND the reasoning behind the decision.
phases.studentRole: Follow the reasoning, note the steps, ask clarifying questions

phases.aiRole: Present scaffolded problems with real-world framing. Ask guiding questions. Let the student drive the calculation and the decision.
phases.studentRole: Attempt each problem, explain reasoning, make and justify decisions

phases.aiRole: Assign independent practice mixing computation with decision-making. Problems should require both math AND written justification.
phases.studentRole: Solve independently, compare options, explain choices with evidence

phases.aiRole: Deliver a short assessment mixing computation and scenario-based reasoning. Evaluate both accuracy and quality of justification.
phases.studentRole: Complete the check, show work, defend decisions with numbers

aiDecisionRights: Choose realistic financial scenarios appropriate for the student's maturity level
Adjust complexity based on percent/decimal fluency observed
Spiral in prior skills (percent, budgeting) when relevant to new topics
Push for written justification, not just numerical answers
Flag common real-world traps (minimum payments, predatory lending) during instruction

aiGuidanceNotes: This course is about decision-making, not just computation. Every problem should end with 'so what does this mean for you?' Students must learn to justify financial choices with numbers. Avoid abstract problems — use realistic dollar amounts, actual tax rates (estimate 22-25% for federal+state+FICA), and plausible life scenarios. When teaching credit and debt, be honest about traps without being preachy.
